canonical_explanation.text: Soil is the top layer of the Earth's surface where plants grow. There are three main types of soil: sandy soil (loose, has large particles, drains water quickly, not very good for most plants), clayey soil (sticky when wet, has very fine particles, holds water tightly, used for making pots), and loamy soil (a mixture of sand, clay, and humus, best for growing plants). Humus is the dark-coloured decayed remains of dead plants and animals in soil. Humus makes soil fertile and provides nutrients for plants. Rocks are hard, solid materials found on Earth. They can be as big as mountains or as small as pebbles. Rocks are made up of minerals. Minerals are natural substances found in rocks and the Earth. Important minerals include iron (used for building), gold (used for jewellery), diamond (hardest natural substance), salt (used for cooking), and coal (used as fuel). Natural resources are things we get from nature that are useful to us, such as water, air, soil, minerals, forests, and sunlight. Renewable resources can be replaced naturally (water, forests, sunlight, wind). Non-renewable resources take millions of years to form and cannot be easily replaced (coal, oil, natural gas, minerals). Conservation means saving and protecting natural resources. We can conserve by saving water, planting trees, reducing waste, recycling, and avoiding pollution.
rules: Soil is the top layer of Earth where plants grow
Sandy soil: loose, drains water fast, not great for plants
Clayey soil: sticky, holds water, used for making pots
Loamy soil: mix of sand, clay, and humus, best for plants
Humus: decayed remains of plants and animals, makes soil fertile
Rocks are hard solid materials made of minerals
Important minerals: iron, gold, diamond, salt, coal
Natural resources: water, air, soil, minerals, forests, sunlight
Renewable resources: can be replaced (water, forests, sunlight)
Non-renewable resources: cannot be easily replaced (coal, oil, minerals)
Conservation: saving and protecting natural resources
Ways to conserve: save water, plant trees, reduce waste, recycle

questions.question_text: What is soil?

options.text: The top layer of the Earth where plants grow

questions.explanation_correct: Soil is the top layer of the Earth's surface. It is made up of tiny rock particles, minerals, water, air, and decayed plant and animal matter (humus). Soil is where most plants grow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hard rocks are not soil (though soil comes from weathered rocks over time). Underground water and air are not soil. Soil is specifically the top layer of earth that supports plant growth.

questions.question_text: Sandy soil has which properties?

options.text: It is sticky and holds lots of water
It is loose, has large particles, and drains water quickly
It is the best soil for growing all plants
It is very dark in colour

questions.explanation_correct: Sandy soil is loose, has large particles, and lets water drain through quickly. Because it does not hold water well, it is not ideal for most plants. Desert areas have sandy soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sticky soil that holds water is clayey soil. The best soil for plants is loamy soil. Dark soil is rich in humus. Sandy soil is specifically loose with large particles and fast water drainage.

questions.question_text: Clayey soil is used for making pots because it is:

options.text: Sticky when wet and can be moulded into shapes

questions.explanation_correct: Clayey soil becomes sticky when wet and can be easily moulded into shapes. This is why potters use clay to make pots, cups, and other items. When dried or baked, clay becomes hard and keeps its shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loose, dry, stony, or sandy soil cannot be moulded. Clayey soil is special because its fine particles become sticky when wet, making it perfect for shaping into pots and other objects.

questions.question_text: Which type of soil is best for growing plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Loamy soil is the best for growing plants. It is a mixture of sand, clay, and humus. It holds the right amount of water, has good nutrients from humus, and allows air to reach plant roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sandy soil drains too fast and lacks nutrients. Clayey soil holds too much water. Rocky soil has no nutrients. Loamy soil, being a balanced mixture, provides the ideal conditions for plant growth.

questions.question_text: What is humus?

options.text: Decayed remains of dead plants and animals in soil

questions.explanation_correct: Humus is the dark-coloured material formed from the decay of dead plants and animals. It makes soil rich and fertile by providing nutrients that plants need to grow. Soil with more humus is better for farming.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humus is not rocks, water, or air in the soil. It is specifically the decayed organic matter from dead plants and animals that adds nutrients and fertility to the soil.

questions.question_text: True or False: Loamy soil is a mixture of sand, clay, and humus.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Loamy soil contains a balanced mixture of sand (for drainage), clay (for holding some water), and humus (for nutrients). This combination makes it the best soil for growing most plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Loamy soil is indeed a mixture of sand, clay, and humus. This balanced combination gives it the best properties for plant growth.

questions.question_text: A farmer notices that water drains very quickly from his field and plants are not growing well. What type of soil does his field likely have?
questions.explanation_correct: Sandy soil drains water very quickly because its large particles have big spaces between them. This means plant roots cannot absorb enough water, making it difficult for plants to grow well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clayey soil holds too much water (opposite problem). Loamy soil has good drainage. Humus-rich soil retains moisture. Fast drainage and poor plant growth indicate sandy soil.

questions.question_text: How can a farmer improve sandy soil for better crop growth?

options.text: By adding clay and compost (humus) to it

questions.explanation_correct: Adding clay helps sandy soil hold water better, and adding compost (humus) provides nutrients for plants. This makes the sandy soil more like loamy soil, which is ideal for growing crops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding more sand makes it worse. Removing water and adding rocks does not help. Mixing clay and compost into sandy soil improves its ability to hold water and provide nutrients.

questions.question_text:
Match the soil type with its property:
1. Sandy soil - (a) Best for plants
2. Clayey soil - (b) Drains water fast
3. Loamy soil - (c) Sticky when wet

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Sandy soil drains water fast (1-b), Clayey soil is sticky when wet (2-c), and Loamy soil is best for plants (3-a). Each soil type has distinct properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Sandy = drains fast (loose), Clayey = sticky (holds water), Loamy = best for plants (balanced). The correct matching is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a.

questions.question_text: The dark-coloured material in soil that comes from decayed plants and animals is called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Humus is the dark-coloured organic matter in soil formed from decayed plants and animals. It is rich in nutrients and makes soil fertile. Gardens with good humus grow healthy plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sand and gravel are mineral particles, and clay is fine mineral particles. The dark organic matter from decomposed plants and animals is specifically called humus.

questions.question_text: What are rocks?

options.text: Hard, solid materials found on Earth

questions.explanation_correct: Rocks are hard, solid materials found on and inside the Earth. They come in different sizes - from huge mountains to small pebbles. Rocks are made up of one or more minerals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rocks are not soft, not a type of soil, and not decayed plants. They are hard, solid natural materials found on Earth in various sizes, from mountain-sized to tiny pebbles.

questions.question_text: Minerals are:

options.text: Natural substances found in rocks and the Earth

questions.explanation_correct: Minerals are natural substances found in rocks and the Earth. They have specific chemical compositions. Examples include iron, gold, diamond, salt, and coal. Minerals have many uses in our daily lives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Minerals are not man-made, not plants, and not water. They are natural substances found in rocks that have been formed over millions of years inside the Earth.

questions.question_text: Which mineral is used for building bridges and making tools?
questions.explanation_correct: Iron is used for building bridges, buildings, tools, and many other structures. It is strong and durable. Iron ore is mined from the Earth and processed to make steel, which is used in construction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold is used for jewellery (too soft for building). Diamond is used for cutting (too expensive for building). Salt is for cooking. Iron is the mineral used for building and making tools.

questions.question_text: Which is the hardest natural substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Diamond is the hardest natural substance found on Earth. It is so hard that it can scratch any other material. Diamonds are used in jewellery and also for cutting and drilling tools.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is strong but can be scratched. Gold is actually quite soft. Coal is brittle. Diamond is the hardest natural substance, which is why it is used to cut other hard materials.

questions.question_text: We add salt to our food for taste. Where does salt come from?

options.text: It is made in factories from chemicals
It is a mineral found in the Earth and in sea water

questions.explanation_correct: Salt is a mineral. It is found in rock form underground (rock salt) and dissolved in sea water. Sea salt is obtained by evaporating sea water. The Sambhar Lake in Rajasthan is a famous source of salt in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While salt is processed in factories, it originally comes from nature. Salt is a mineral found in the Earth (rock salt) and in sea water. It does not come from plants or animals.

questions.question_text: True or False: All rocks are the same size.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Rocks come in all sizes. Mountains are made of huge rocks, while pebbles on a beach are tiny rocks. Even sand grains are extremely small pieces of rock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Rocks range from enormous mountain-sized formations to tiny pebbles and even sand grains. Rocks come in many different sizes.

questions.question_text:
Match the mineral with its use:
1. Iron - (a) Jewellery
2. Gold - (b) Cooking
3. Salt - (c) Building
4. Coal - (d) Fuel

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Iron is used for building (1-c), Gold is used for jewellery (2-a), Salt is used in cooking (3-b), and Coal is used as fuel (4-d). Each mineral has specific important uses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Iron = building/construction, Gold = jewellery, Salt = cooking/food, Coal = fuel/energy. The correct matching is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d.

questions.question_text: Natural resources are:

options.text: Things from nature that are useful to us

questions.explanation_correct: Natural resources are things we get from nature that are useful to us. They include water, air, soil, minerals, forests, sunlight, and wildlife. We depend on natural resources for survival.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Factory-made items are not natural resources. Toys and games are man-made. Natural resources are specifically things found in nature that humans and other living things use.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a natural resource?
questions.explanation_correct: Water is a natural resource found in rivers, lakes, oceans, and underground. It is essential for all life. Plastic bags, televisions, and mobile phones are man-made products, not natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic bags, televisions, and mobile phones are made by humans in factories. Water is the natural resource in this list - it occurs naturally and is essential for all life on Earth.

questions.question_text: Renewable resources are those that:

options.text: Can be replaced or replenished by nature

questions.explanation_correct: Renewable resources can be replaced or replenished by nature over time. Examples include water (rain replenishes it), forests (trees can be replanted), sunlight, and wind. They will not run out if used wisely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resources that cannot be replaced are non-renewable. Renewable resources can be naturally replenished, like water through the water cycle, trees through planting, and sunlight which comes daily.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a non-renewable resource?
questions.explanation_correct: Coal is a non-renewable resource. It took millions of years to form from dead plants buried deep underground. Once we use up all the coal, we cannot make more. Oil and natural gas are also non-renewable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight, wind, and water are all renewable resources that nature replenishes. Coal took millions of years to form and cannot be quickly replaced, making it non-renewable.

questions.question_text: Why should we use non-renewable resources carefully?

options.text: Because they take millions of years to form and will run out if overused

questions.explanation_correct: Non-renewable resources like coal, oil, and minerals took millions of years to form inside the Earth. If we use them too quickly, they will run out and cannot be replaced in our lifetime. We must use them wisely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-renewable resources ARE useful and valuable. The concern is that they will run out because they cannot be quickly replaced. We must conserve them for future generations.

questions.question_text: True or False: Sunlight is a non-renewable resource.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Sunlight is a renewable resource. The Sun provides light and heat every day and will continue to do so for billions of years. Solar energy is one of the best renewable energy sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Sunlight is a renewable resource because it is available every day and does not get used up. The Sun will keep shining for billions of years.

questions.question_text: Which group contains ONLY renewable resources?
questions.explanation_correct: Sunlight, wind, and water are all renewable resources. Sunlight comes every day, wind blows continuously, and water is recycled through the water cycle. They can be used without running out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal, oil, and natural gas are non-renewable. Iron, gold, and diamond are non-renewable minerals. Coal mixed with renewable resources is not all renewable. Only sunlight, wind, and water are all renewable.

questions.question_text: Conservation means:

options.text: Using resources as fast as possible

questions.explanation_correct: Conservation means saving, protecting, and using natural resources wisely so that they last for a long time and are available for future generations. It includes reducing waste, reusing items, and recycling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using resources quickly and wasting them are the opposite of conservation. Buying more does not help either. Conservation is about saving and protecting resources for the future.

questions.question_text: Which of these helps conserve water?

options.text: Turning off taps when not in use
Using a hose pipe to wash the car every day

questions.explanation_correct: Turning off taps when not in use saves a lot of water. A dripping tap can waste thousands of litres of water over time. Simple actions like turning off taps while brushing teeth help conserve water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaving taps running, wasting water while brushing, and using hose pipes daily all waste water. The simplest way to conserve water is to turn off taps when they are not being used.

questions.question_text: Planting more trees helps conserve natural resources because:

options.text: Trees are pretty to look at
Trees give us oxygen, prevent soil erosion, and provide habitat for animals

questions.explanation_correct: Trees produce oxygen, absorb carbon dioxide, prevent soil erosion (roots hold soil), provide homes for birds and animals, and give us fruits, wood, and shade. Planting trees is one of the best ways to conserve nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While trees are beautiful, their importance goes far beyond looks. Trees play crucial roles in giving oxygen, preventing soil erosion, providing animal habitat, and maintaining the ecological balance.

questions.question_text: Reema uses both sides of paper for writing. How does this help conservation?

options.text: It does not help at all
It reduces the amount of paper needed, which saves trees
It makes her writing look better

questions.explanation_correct: Using both sides of paper means fewer sheets are needed. Paper is made from trees, so using less paper means fewer trees need to be cut down. This is a simple but effective way to conserve forests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using both sides definitely helps conservation. Paper comes from trees. By using less paper, we save trees and forests. It is not about appearance or paper strength.

questions.question_text: Which of these is the best way to reduce waste?

options.text: Follow the three Rs: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle

questions.explanation_correct: The three Rs are: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (make new things from old materials). This approach helps reduce waste, save resources, and protect the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing everything in garbage, burning waste, and dumping in rivers all harm the environment. The best approach is Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (convert to new products).

questions.question_text: True or False: Switching off lights and fans when leaving a room helps conserve electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Switching off lights, fans, and other electrical appliances when not needed saves electricity. Much of India's electricity comes from burning coal, so saving electricity also conserves coal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Turning off electrical appliances when not in use is one of the simplest ways to conserve electricity and the resources used to generate it.

questions.question_text: Why are forests considered a valuable natural resource?

options.text: Because forests give oxygen, prevent soil erosion, provide homes for wildlife, and regulate climate
Because forests are dark and mysterious

questions.explanation_correct: Forests are extremely valuable because they produce oxygen, absorb carbon dioxide, prevent soil erosion, are home to countless species of plants and animals, and help regulate the climate and water cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Forests do much more than just provide wood or shade. They play multiple critical roles in maintaining the Earth's environment, biodiversity, and climate.

questions.question_text: Which statement about soil is INCORRECT?

options.text: Soil takes hundreds of years to form
Sandy soil holds the most water
Loamy soil is best for farming

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that sandy soil holds the most water is INCORRECT. Sandy soil actually holds the LEAST water because its large particles have big gaps that let water drain through quickly. Clayey soil holds the most water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil does take centuries to form, humus does make soil fertile, and loamy soil is best for farming. The incorrect statement is about sandy soil - it holds the LEAST water, not the most.

questions.question_text: Coal is sometimes called 'black gold'. Why?

options.text: Because it is shiny like gold
Because it is as expensive as gold
Because it is very valuable as a source of energy
Because it is made from gold

questions.explanation_correct: Coal is called 'black gold' because, like gold, it is extremely valuable. Coal is used as fuel to generate electricity, run factories, and power trains. It is black in colour, and its usefulness makes it as precious as gold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal is not shiny, not as expensive as gold per gram, and is not made from gold. It is called 'black gold' because of its great value as an energy source, despite being black in colour.

questions.question_text: What does 'Reduce' mean in the three Rs?

options.text: Make new things from old materials

questions.explanation_correct: Reduce means to use less of something. For example, using less plastic, less water, less electricity, and less paper. By reducing our consumption, we create less waste and use fewer resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using things again is Reuse. Making new from old is Recycle. Throwing things away is wasteful. Reduce specifically means to use LESS of something.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an example of 'Reuse'?

options.text: Throwing old newspapers in the bin
Using an old glass jar to store spices

questions.explanation_correct: Using an old glass jar to store spices is an example of reuse. Instead of throwing the jar away, you give it a new purpose. Reuse means finding a new way to use something instead of discarding it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing things away and burning them are wasteful. Buying new things constantly is consumption. Reusing means giving old items a new purpose, like using an old jar for storage.

questions.question_text: Resources that cannot be replaced easily and take millions of years to form are called ________ resources.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-renewable resources take millions of years to form and cannot be quickly replaced. Coal, oil, natural gas, and minerals like iron and gold are non-renewable. Once used up, they are gone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Renewable resources CAN be replaced. Infinite resources do not exist. Man-made items are manufactured. Resources that take millions of years to form are called non-renewable.

questions.question_text: Petroleum (crude oil) is sometimes called 'liquid gold'. Why is it so important?

options.text: Because it is used for cooking only
Because it is used to make petrol, diesel, plastics, and many other products
Because it is found in gold mines

questions.explanation_correct: Petroleum is called 'liquid gold' because it is extremely valuable. It is refined to make petrol and diesel (fuel for vehicles), kerosene, LPG, plastics, and many chemicals. Our modern life depends heavily on petroleum products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petroleum does not look like gold and is not found in gold mines. It is called 'liquid gold' because of its immense value in producing fuels, plastics, and hundreds of other essential products.

questions.question_text: Collecting rainwater in tanks for later use is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Rainwater harvesting is the collection and storage of rainwater for later use. Rainwater can be collected from rooftops into tanks and used for gardening, washing, and even drinking after purification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water pollution is contaminating water. The water cycle is a natural process. Evaporation is water turning to gas. Collecting and storing rainwater for use is called rainwater harvesting.

questions.question_text: Soil erosion means:

options.text: The top layer of soil being washed or blown away

questions.explanation_correct: Soil erosion is the washing away or blowing away of the top layer of soil by water and wind. This removes the fertile topsoil that plants need. Cutting trees increases soil erosion because tree roots hold soil in place.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil erosion is not about fertility or planting. It is the harmful removal of topsoil by water (rain, rivers) or wind. Deforestation makes erosion worse because there are no roots to hold soil.

questions.question_text: How can we prevent soil erosion?

options.text: By planting more trees and growing grass
By adding rocks to the soil

questions.explanation_correct: Planting trees and growing grass prevents soil erosion because their roots hold the soil firmly in place. Cutting trees and removing plants expose the soil to wind and water, making erosion worse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting trees and removing plants make erosion WORSE. Adding rocks alone does not help much. Planting trees and growing grass is the best way because roots bind the soil and prevent it from being washed away.

questions.question_text: Air is a natural resource. Why is it important?

options.text: We need oxygen from air to breathe, and plants need carbon dioxide
It is needed only by fish

questions.explanation_correct: Air is vital because it contains oxygen that animals and humans need to breathe, and carbon dioxide that plants need for photosynthesis. Without air, no life could exist on Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While sound does travel through air, its most important role is providing oxygen for breathing and carbon dioxide for plant photosynthesis. Air is needed by all living things, not just fish.

questions.question_text: True or False: Recycling paper helps save trees.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Recycling paper means old paper is turned into new paper, reducing the need to cut down trees for fresh paper. Recycling one tonne of paper can save about 17 trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. When paper is recycled, fewer trees need to be cut down to make new paper. Recycling is one of the most effective ways to conserve forest resources.

questions.question_text: Mountains, pebbles, and sand are all forms of:
questions.explanation_correct: Mountains are very large rocks, pebbles are small rocks, and sand grains are very tiny rock particles. They are all forms of rocks, just in different sizes. Over time, large rocks break down into smaller pieces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil is different from rocks. Minerals make up rocks. Clay is a type of fine particle. Mountains, pebbles, and sand are all rocks in different sizes - from enormous to tiny.

questions.question_text: Which of these actions does NOT help in conservation?
questions.explanation_correct: Throwing plastic in rivers causes pollution and harms water resources and aquatic life. It is the opposite of conservation. Planting trees, saving water, and using paper wisely all help conserve natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting trees, saving water, and using both sides of paper all help conservation. Throwing plastic in rivers is harmful pollution that damages water resources and kills aquatic animals.

questions.question_text: Why is soil considered a valuable natural resource?

options.text: Because it is used to make buildings only
Because almost all our food comes from crops grown in soil
Because it is the same as rocks

questions.explanation_correct: Soil is valuable because almost all our food comes from plants that grow in soil. Grains, vegetables, fruits, and even animal food all depend on soil. Without fertile soil, we cannot grow food to feed people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil is not just for buildings, and it is different from rocks. While soil is found in many places, its main value is that it supports plant growth and food production for all of humanity.

questions.question_text: The three Rs of conservation are Reduce, ________, and Recycle.
questions.explanation_correct: The three Rs are Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again for a different purpose), and Recycle (process old materials into new products). Together, these three actions help conserve resources and reduce waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While removing, replacing, and repairing can be helpful, the official three Rs of conservation are Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. Reuse means using something again instead of throwing it away.

questions.question_text: After heavy rain, a farmer's field has water standing on it for days. What type of soil does the field likely have?
questions.explanation_correct: Clayey soil has very fine particles that are packed closely together, leaving little space for water to drain through. This is why water stays on the surface of clayey soil for a long time after rain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sandy soil would drain water fast, and loamy soil has balanced drainage. Standing water for days indicates clayey soil, which has fine particles that hold water very tightly.

questions.question_text: What can children do to help conserve natural resources?

options.text: Save water, switch off lights when not needed, and plant trees
Use as many plastic bags as possible
Nothing, conservation is only for adults

questions.explanation_correct: Children can help by saving water (turning off taps), saving electricity (switching off lights and fans), planting trees, using less plastic, and recycling. Every small action counts towards conservation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conservation is everyone's responsibility, including children. Wasting resources and using plastic harm the environment. Simple actions like saving water and planting trees make a real difference.

questions.question_text: Which of these correctly classifies resources as renewable and non-renewable?

options.text: Renewable: coal, oil; Non-renewable: water, sunlight
Renewable: water, sunlight, wind; Non-renewable: coal, oil, minerals
Renewable: diamonds, gold; Non-renewable: water, air

questions.explanation_correct: Water, sunlight, and wind are renewable (they get replenished naturally). Coal, oil, and minerals are non-renewable (they took millions of years to form and cannot be quickly replaced).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal and oil are non-renewable, not renewable. Water and sunlight are renewable, not non-renewable. Diamonds and gold are non-renewable minerals. Not all resources are renewable.

questions.question_text: True or False: If we do not conserve natural resources, future generations may not have enough resources to survive.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. If we use non-renewable resources too quickly, pollute water and air, and destroy forests, future generations will face shortages of essential resources. Conservation ensures there is enough for everyone, now and in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Natural resources are limited, especially non-renewable ones. If we waste them today, our children and grandchildren may not have enough water, fuel, minerals, or clean air to survive.
